review.title: Optimizing Gross Merchandise Volume via DNN-MAB Dynamic Ranking Paradigm
review.abstract: With the transition from people's traditional `brick-and-mortar' shopping to online mobile shopping patterns in web 2.0 $\mathit{era}$, the recommender system plays a critical role in E-Commerce and E-Retails. This is especially true when designing this system for more than $\mathbf{236~million}$ daily active users. Ranking strategy, the key module of the recommender system, needs to be precise, accurate, and responsive for estimating customers' intents. We propose a dynamic ranking paradigm, named as DNN-MAB, that is composed of a pairwise deep neural network (DNN) $\mathit{pre}$-ranker connecting a revised multi-armed bandit (MAB) dynamic $\mathit{post}$-ranker. By taking into account of explicit and implicit user feedbacks such as impressions, clicks, conversions, etc. DNN-MAB is able to adjust DNN $\mathit{pre}$-ranking scores to assist customers locating items they are interested in most so that they can converge quickly and frequently. To the best of our knowledge, frameworks like DNN-MAB have not been discussed in the previous literature to either E-Commerce or machine learning audiences. In practice, DNN-MAB has been deployed to production and it easily outperforms against other state-of-the-art models by significantly lifting the gross merchandise volume (GMV) which is the objective metrics at JD.

sections.heading: 1 INTRODUCTION
sections.text: The key to the success of e-commerce websites and applications is effectively generating the right list of items for customers. How quickly and how often customers can converge their shopping needs in real time will determine whether the e-commerce company would thrive. To meet this challenge, the Referral System, an information filtering, rating and referral engine that helps users reach a small group of items that describe and satisfy their buying needs in real time, was created. Founded in 2004, JD has quickly become one of the most popular e-commerce websites in China. Customers come to JD to discover, browse and buy what themselves and over hundreds of thousands of other government-certified e-retailers do.

sections.heading: 1.1 Contributions
sections.text: This paper contains two primary contributions in research and industry: 1. an innovative ranking paradigm to solve the dynamic ranking problem by combining the pair-deep neural Xiv: 170 8.03 993v 1 [cs.A I] 1 4A ug2 017network and multi-arm bandit algorithms; 2. a revised Thompson sampling algorithm with the brand new production use-case initialization strategy that enables rapid customer convergence.

sections.heading: 1.2 Organization
sections.text: The rest of this paper is broken down as follows: Section 2 briefly describes the recommendation system used in JD and discusses the ranking module in detail: 2.3 Learning-to-Rank DNN module as pre-ranking and 2.4 MAB Thompson sampling as post-ranking; Section 3 first describes a simple case study that simulates the real world to test how Thompson's sampling works in comparison to other popular MAB algorithms, and then reports on the proposed DNN-MAB performance in terms of various metrics; Section 4 discusses some prominent related studies in terms of recommendation systems, learning-to-rank using deep neural network models and multi-arm bandit models; we summarize our work and outline some future directions in Section 5.

sections.heading: 2.1 System design
sections.text: Our recommendation system in Fig.2 consists of three main function modules: the item retrieval module, the item post retrieval module and the ranking module. Users typically trigger the recommendation system from the direction of the mobile application point or from our mobile version websites. After the system specifies the identities of the users, the recommender makes a search request to the user database and the item database for further information relating to user profiles such as gender, geo-location, purchase history, price sensitivity, etc. This information, combined with the items that users have recently clicked on or placed in the shopping basket, is collected and serves as an input of the retrieval system. Next, the retrieval system selects a large pool of candidate items that are related to the input item. The motivation for the post retrieval module 2005 consists of selecting items that are already qualified by the item, including items that are not suitable for retrieval by the item category.

sections.heading: 3.2 Experiment setup
sections.text: JD handles billions of requests every day, and any new models that are about to be launched must be evaluated by JD's online testing platform. It splits the real data streams into 10 groups, with each of these groups receiving about 8% of total traffic and the remaining 20% held by the control group. We use the proposed dynamic ranking paradigm on this platform for 7 days and follow the following metrics: GMV, job numbers, total (Eq.1) and page-by-page (Eq.5) discounted cumulative profits (dcgg).dcgp, page − k = i = p х i = 1, k ² page gmvkiI (xki) log2 (i + 1) (5) Since the article lists are presented to users page by page and each page contains 4-20 articles, dcgp is a perfect metric for assessing how the revised Thompson module works in practice and how much profit we have observed it should be credited to it (8).

sections.heading: 3.3 Production performance
sections.text: We report on the performance between DNN-MAB and DNNrt-ft as the starting point in Tab.1. DNN-rt-ft is to leverage the DNN pre-ranking, considering both the feedback from offline users and online surfing and click signals as characteristics for training a nearline model that is only better than models that take offline signals. On average, we see that DNN-MAB's daily GMV has increased 16.69% via DNN-rt-ft. Any performance gains greater than 1.0% over 7 days are considered statistically significant in the real production system. DNN-MAB paradigm has clearly demonstrated its superiority over the current DNN rt-ft ranking strategy. To emphasize the importance of parameter initialization and feedback revision in Thompson-sampling, we also report on DNN + NormalThompson in Tab.2. Due to the spatial limitation of DNN-rt-ft ranking strategy, we do not simply go to DNN's final page, but rather to the DNN's very detailed DNB page.

sections.heading: 4 RELATED WORK
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 4.1 Recommender system
sections.text: The recommendation system is the key to the success of e-commerce websites and other indexing service providers such as Alibaba, Ebay, Google, Baidu, Youtube, etc. Efforts by various parties to design recommendation systems include [Linden et al., 2003; Davidson et al., 2010; Schafer et al., 2001; Sarwar et al., 2000]. Generally, there are two workflows in the recommendation system: content-based approaches and item-based approaches represent users and items as a huge M by N matrix and focus on learning the underlying relationships between items. Works of item-based approaches such as [Sarwar et al., 2001; Rendle et al., 2010] have all had tremendous success. However, item-based approaches suffer from issues such as cold start, scalability and plasticity, etc.

sections.heading: 4.3 Contextual multi-armed bandit problems
sections.text: The problem of multi-armed bandits has been well studied and discussed in literature such as [Lai and Robbins, 1985; Even-Dar et al., 2006; Auer et al., 2002] The basic approach for MAB is to select K-elements from M-arms successively with feedback, thus minimizing overall expectations. Thompson samples taken from [Thompson, 1933], despite their simplicity in terms of production performance [Tang et al., 2013; Chapelle and Li, 2011] have proven to be quite efficient and surprisingly easy to implement. Further work on Thompson sample models includes [Scott, 2010].

sections.heading: 5 CONCLUSION
sections.text: We have proposed a dynamic ranking paradigm called DNNMAB, consisting of Learning-to-Rank DNN Preranker and Revised-Thompson Post-Ranker. This effective ranking paradigm takes into account both the user and the item information, so that the DNN could achieve decent static ranking performance. In the meantime, the Revised-Thompson sample has been able to adjust the pre-rankings, which further increase the objective ratios. To our knowledge, such a ranking framework has not been discussed in previous research. Real production tests show that both GMVs and DCGs have improved significantly. However, for the sake of simplicity, we have not paid too much attention to the positioning distortion, which is an important factor influencing ranking performance [Radlinski et al., 2008] in the Learning-to-Rank DNN Pre-Ranker, which would bring the listing problem into some scalability.
